iuGIgVmwCWbNc0YRk4fqsQ.text: Ryoshi Sushi Ikeikemaru is definitely one of my top Japanese food haunts. At least weekly visits are a must and being a loyal fan, it is no wonder that the restaurant was made one of my choices for Liang Court's Oishi Food Trail.I love Ryoshi's Iced Green Tea ($1.80, free-flow) and have also tried many of their different sushi types. This time, however, I got to taste more than just the sushi with their VERY generous meal provided in conjunction with the food trail.The set at Ryoshi consisted of Salad with Prawns, 5 pieces of Nigiri Sushi (Salmon, Tamago, Ika, Maguro and Ebi), Uni-topped Beancurd, Okura Ponzu, 6 pieces of Sashimi (2 X Salmon, 2 X Maguro, 1 X Akagai and 1 X Tako), Assorted Tempura (includes Ebi, Lotus Root, Nasu Eggplant, Okra and Tuna) and a simple Dessert.As always, the sushi and sashimi were fresh and good, especially the "Big Salmon" sushi and Maguro Sashimi which had more tender cuts than most other sushi restaurants and melted in the mouth. The Uni-topped beancurd was amazing, no doubt due to the creamy umami provided by the sea urchin gonads. What truly stood out, however, was the Assorted Tempura.The tempura batter and sauce prepared by Ryoshi Sushi is simply outstanding, converting even a friend who does not eat fried food. The sauce was so delicious I was tempted to take a spoon to it when I have regretfully finished the rest of my Tempura. Definitely a dish I would order when I next return.For many more pictures and the full review visit voraciousappetite.wordpr…

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore

nZnFywM8ThHMsKUnEWoMbg.text: Simply the best sushi I recently tried. The place has just opened and has several affordable menu with aggressive prices. I tried a 6 pieces sushi menu with salad, miso soup and green tea for 13 SGD! Very high quality and generous portions. Excellent service too.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore

lvvWuIJAw3KnqJe683dJMw.text: Had a great time with our family over here. It has a very wide selection of Nigiri Sushis, in fact easily the widest among the Japanese restaurants in Singapore.

-BTy4f03QA8TWbwfrxBReA.text: I'm confused.Do I like Ikeikemaru more? Or do I like Itacho more?Is Ikeikemaru cheaper? No... not really. My companion and I ended paying $40 each, which is a little less than what I'd probably have paid at Itacho for a similiar amount, but not by much. There were a lot of Japanese dining there though, which probably means that compared to the Taiwan-originating Itacho, the flavours are a lot more authentic (I guess? I didn't notice that.)Personally?Good sushi (I didn't try any sashimi). The various mackerel items, the seared salmon, the vinegared fish, I enjoyed it all and often ordered second helpings of each. They're definitely very generous with the fish, and the little rice is pretty tasty. Some items lost out to their counterparts at Itacho, and some were undeniably better. This place definitely does aburi much better, and all the items get a good, solid sear. And while I enjoyed  I can't shake the feeling that Ikeikemaru is a little overrated.It's not as cheap as everyone makes it out to be (in my opinion), and while it's good, solid sushi, it's also not revolutionary. I think Ikeikemaru completely blows places like Sushi Tei and Sakae Sushi out of the water, but frankly, I don't understand how those places haven't closed down to begin with. This place is a solid, reliable option for sushi, and I'll definitely be back.But is it "the best budget sushi place in town"? I can't really say yes.

9nZhl4JYYtn3_h9Cif3svw.text: If my guess is correct, it is the exact sushi shop from Shizuoka. The space where Ryoshi now stands used to change tenants a lot but I guess the business here is so good that it is going to stay for long. The Jizakama Rayu (fish seasoned in chilli oil) is as mild as it looks while the Fuwafuwa Tamago is creamy but bland.I guessed we were in better luck when we ordered the recommended items like the Nama Shirasu ($5.80). The overflowing amount of raw whitebait was a pleasant sight that no one would complain that it's too much. But the large piece of eel in Daimyo Anago($5.80) shown below failed to impress the eyes and the taste buds. It needs more sun-tanning.Notice the absence of raw fish? That is because we prefer to have it as plain sashimi but they did not have it. Nonetheless, this did not disappoint as their non-sushi items were actually tastier! Salmon salad ($8.60) is drizzled in bright and tangy dressing while the Fried Oysters ($6.80) are plump, juicy and cheap. The Pumpkin Croquette $4.80 was another of our hot favourite because it was not simply puréed pumpkin but also contain pumpkin bits. Served piping hot, they did require some self-discipline to not bite into them immediately but worth the wait.....

bUOzF7gGp3TTP8aSsWiNLQ.text: Fantastic value for quality! One of the best sushi plus really affordable prices.. Awesome :) recommended by professional foodie Chris Tan, with gd reason! Large pieces of fish w little rice. Mm. Aburi salmon was delicious! Friend loved the aburi cheese ebi. Whole anago was pretty gd (although I think itacho sushi's could give this one a run for its money, bigger slice for $6.50 as compared to $6.80 here).Lots of aburi choices, my fav!Vinegared mackerel was pretty gd. Engawa (fluke fin) was new to me but apparently a sushi standard so wanted to try it out. Texture reminded me somewhat of squid, interesting..Anyway, really good quality sushi and in all cost ~$16! Will definitely be back for more :)

ZDIpDa5E3sBLziNy2fQn8w.text: It didn't blow my face off but it was good. The service was a little off, as in I was trying to wave people down for 20 minutes to order. The tuna bowl at lunch was big enough that I shouldn't have eaten as much (or any) sushi off the conveyor belt beforehand. The tuna sashimi seemed high quality and had no visible fat. The ground tuna (if that's what it was) in the middle of the tuna bowl was remarkably delicious and succulent.

FmS2hk_D9SPe5MXUPdPZ7g.text: Was impressed with the selection. Kimedai! Shima Aji at a conveyor belt sushi joint? alas...it was not up to expectation. Everything tasted bleah. The fish seemed to be treated with some chemicals. tuna was inedible.Pass. You get what you pay for. Am not a sushi snob, but don't serve up sub-par fish as quality fish.

j9g6t2-XWZw0c8fqQUFxow.text: If you are looking for a slightly more authentic Japanese sushi experience than Sushi Tei or Itacho, but don't want to burn your pockets, this is a great place to go to. It's run by mostly Japanese, and on top of the usual sushi menu, served the old school conveyor belt style, they always have a ton of seasonal fish and even fresh wasabi and home-made desserts. The fish quality is pretty comparable to Itacho, but you get a lot more variety, and it makes you feel just a little closer to Japan.

lEMdYHaIh7Q8ZGlp33_J3g.text: Not bad authentic sushi joint in town. The good thing about this plc is they serves lotsa types of fish that are unusual which makes you feel like trying all of it. I prefer going here than itacho sushi n you'll see lotsa japanese eating in here too.

dLhS4J8tpqyz4tlLuhlm_w.text: Great place for sushi without breaking the bank. Was amazed at the number of Japanese diners there, so that's always a good sign! I loved the aburi salmon, was delish! Hubby swooned over the otoro nigiri and enjoyed the oysters. With the sushi train right in front, it really is a test of your discipline and willpower! Our dinner wasn't as cheap as in the other reviews (almost $100 for the two of us and no alcohol!) but I guess that goes back to the point on discipline and willpower! Haha

xRXJTIrwhrDONWUhOyOvdA.text: Absolutely wonderful. Don't be fooled by the conveyor belt into thinking its some crappy sushi chain like Sakae Sushi and the like. No this is true authentic Japanese sushi, with Japanese staff and a Japanese sushi chef, the experience truly is authentic. The sushi itself is wonderful, fresh and generous cuts of fish. Pricing wise its extremely affordable when compared to restaurants like Tampopo upstairs.The best deal i would recommend is getting the Tempura Udon with a Sushi Set add-on. At around $15 ($9 udon, $6 add-on for sushi) its definitely worth it, especially since there's no service charge and GST (if I remember correctly). The tempura udon comes with 3 Ebi Tempura (a rarity since most places only give 1) with one of the best bowls if udons I've ever had. The soup borth for the udon is fragrant and delicious while the homemade udon is definitely different from your standard Udon as its thin rather than fat. The smooth texture of the udon with the tasty soup broth makes it one of the top Udon in Singapore.The $6.80 add-on for the sushi set is definitely one of the most value-for-money deals out there. At $6.80 you can get a mediocre plate of sushi at Sakar Sushi (:/) But here, you can a variety of seven sushi. Salmon, Tuna, Squid, Mackerel (or Sardine), Egg, Ebi (Prawn), Beancurd skin Sushi. The salmon and tuna sushi were the best I've eaten in a long time, the fish is very fresh, the cut of fish is thick and you can taste the natural sweetness of the fish. The rice is also moist and fluffy unlike another chain (Sushi Tei) The sushi is definitely one of the best around and definitely one of the cheapest around with its authentic taste, presentation and freshness of ingredients.I would definitely recommend this place to sushi lovers. Although its been only open for less than a month, its usually packed during dinner. Though there hasn't been queues yet, the restaurant is usually full house.

nC8-obR_Iv48wdw1hAsBlQ.text: The price seemed really high for the Buffett like quality fish that was being offered. I expected more from a place with the reviews it received from yelp. I'm assuming that these people haven't had good sushi in their life time.

_svStBGac1yuvQd666fJ8A.text: Disappointing. Firstly, I was put off by this waitress who told me to look for the sushi that I wanted from the conveyor belt instead of ordering straight from them. secondly, she was put off by the fact that I was carrying some durians which I sealed in a container, tied with a plastic bag and stored inside a paperbag. Basically there were hardly any smell detected but then I guess she must have a very sharp nose and told us not to eat the durians in the restaurant. Oh please! Why would I do that? Thirdly, the uni gunkan maki sushi was not fresh coz it taste bit bitter and sourish. However, I do like their aburi cheese ebi. Overall, pricey sushi and more suited to Japanese taste buds rather than local tastebud.

6XP8DTiIpqv_SH-Z05Uaaw.text: The restaurant was located at the far end of the basement of the shopping mall. It looked like another rotating sushi restaurant at first sight until one saw the price range of the plates on the belt : from S$1.80++ to S$15.40++. Quite eye popping! Although it was a weekday lunch, the place was packed easily. There was reasonable price lunch set menu, but most were having ala carte. Hot green tea was chargeable at S$1.80++ and was refillable.Kaisen Don Set (S$33++)Served with soup & saladI was kind of surprised to see sea urchin in the dish, as I remembered that the staff who took my order, told me that sea urchin was not available and would be replaced by otoro (fatty tuna). The raw seafood was quite fresh.Mentaiko Scallop Sushi (S$6.80++)It was taken off the rotating conveyor belt. As it was black plate, it was priced S$6.80++ a plate. The rich creamy sauce on the silky juicy scallop was a match.Kaki Fried (S$8.60++)The deep fried oyster was served with mayonnaise by the side. Encased with a thin crispy crust, it was juicy inside, with juicy dipping when bite.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore

jQ2uKNo3fdULRui8-20LQw.text: Popped by here on a weekday late afternoon for a light lunch. We had chicken karaage, sashimi platter, seaweed somen, various things from the sushi train, and tempura. My karaage was in rather large pieces and I would have preferred it in smaller pieces but that's ok. It didn't come with mayonnaise and I asked for some. I like the food here. Simple, easy, and fresh. Nothing fancy, just your usual staples here. I also like that they take Amex cards. Good place to come to, after shopping at Meidi-Ya.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Some plates on the conveyor belt were not covered?!?
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Sashimi platter
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Tempura

khlM_UqzxyhFhUwHDdkFfw.text: This is where I go when I'm in the mood to indulge in sushi. Love the fresh and wide range of selections they have, from tuna, salmon, hamachi, mackerel, scallops, ama ebi and more!

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore

5UfaBcLquoh89ZVzHb4bUg.text: I'm not sure if it's because I went "late" or what but this place was thoroughly disappointing. I walked in at 7:30pm which i thought was not very late.I'm not a fan of conveyor belt sushi (unless I absolutely have to) so I ordered salmon aburi from the menu thinking I would get a fresh one this way. However, i'm pretty sure they just served one right off the conveyor belt anyways. The rice was tough and had dried on the sides. Gross!!!To add more, the rest of the sushi items were served with incorrect temperature (too cold) rendering nearly all of the fish tasteless. It makes me really sad when fish die and their death is wasted on sub-par meal.AND the worst part - the chawanmushi was too salty. How could they, as a japanese restaurant, mess up good ol' chawanmushi??FYI I have been here three times and the quality keeps dropping on each visit. First visit about two years ago was pleasant. Second visit, the waiter blamed me for not checking the bill before she rang up the register (Was it my job to ensure items billed are correct? How about billing the right items in the first place?). Third visit is what I described above.So based on this trend, I won't be coming back. It was not a pleasant experience for $30-40 per person price tag.

nikuRYgTVXGb2yDma57YWw.text: This was introduced to me as having really decent conveyer belt sushi and since it was close to where I live, why not? Right? Apparently, nope. Out of all the sushi I had, only the aburi salmon was decent and that was also because they had slathered so much pollock roe on to mask the taste of the sushi. The fish was definitely too cold and this blunted the taste. Some of them definitely did not seem fresh. The rice was hard and dried along the sides. I've had good sushi but then again, I've had Ikeikemaru Ryoshi. Next time I'm craving for cheap conveyer belt sushi, I'm heading back to Genki.

2SCiDEHCtBGgGPpKquSkzQ.text: Fairly decent Japanese conveyor belt sushi outlet. Good selection of sashimi, with seasonal offerings. Standard sashimi rice bowl and noodle selection, and not much else. A rare find in these days of bloated menus and wacko out there sushi (by which I am definitely referring to the mediocre absurdities found at sakae, sushi tei and regrettably ichiban boshi). Food quality is decent - sashimi is fresh and not so cold as to offer an convincing impression of a meaty ice cube. Sushi rice is properly vinegared. Again, and very tragically, a rare offering these days. That said, sakuraya still holds the crown for nearly-alive sashimi freshness, at least among local sushi chains. Docking a couple stars for the surly service (yes its Singapore but still one must have standards), and the really awful iPad ordering system - truly no due consideration to us plebs who have to actually use the damn thing. UX designers, there's a business opportunity for you in designing these iPad ordering system thingies. All in, a decent place for sushi, and that's saying something considering the good selection in Liang Court (or Singapore for that matter). Will come again.

xadDYjrTuhjEsjyhVmNlYA.text: Love the reasonable priced very fresh sushi and sashimi like everyone else but the real star is their udon.  They serve the Kishimen flat noodle type from Nagoya and it's absolutely fantastic served in a variety of styles.  My favourite is the Tempura Udon which comes with 3 gorgeous tempura prawns.  Next time you go try the Udon for a change of pace and you won't be disappointed!

QdG_nerKreevCJ-vs-AWOQ.text: Good quality sushi restaurant in Singapore. Given it is a kaiten (revolving sushi), price is reasonable. I wish i stay close by so i can go there more often. Muat try: hamachi sushi (yellow tail), scallop sushi and the fatty tuna one.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Hamachi

WDM4DqxDlA04paYAhrJ5eA.text: Consider it my good deed for today that I will share with you were to find Ikeikemaru Ryoshi, otherwise you may spend 30 minutes wandering the mall trying to find it. It is located on the basement floor in the grocery store eating area, far in a back corner to the right. Once inside you will be impressed by the approachable Japanese staff and the mile long conveyer belt. Take a seat and get comfy. It's sushi time!For having dropped only $20 on a respectable amount of sushi, Ikeikemaru wins points in my book. While everyone can't seem to get enough of the aburi salmon, it was my least favorite plate. Living on the US west coast, we are salmon snobs. The salmon was fine, just nothing to rave about. The katsuo, on the otherhand, was to die for. Super fresh with great texture. Could have eaten 3 plates, easily. The tamago was another standout. I'm a huge fan of basic ingredients treated in time honored ways. The tamago is made fresh in house, and the balance of mirin against the creamy egg was spot on. So good. Ikeikemaru Ryoshi has definitely made its way into the quick and easy dinner rotation list!

QwlygAH7IFvrUT9ivcdbZw.text: Chanced upon this restaurant for dinner while shopping at Westgate with a friend. It was not crowded which was good enough for me in comparison to the popular brand names like Tim Ho Wan and Ding Tai Feng which were, needless to say, decorated with long queues on a Sat night.This place is mainly for sushi. Concept is typical of a conveyor belt sushi bars we've probably all been to before- However, a distinguishing factor would probably be the sushi chefs doing their thing at the island where customers can watch them work while we eat. Friend and I initially ordered a Udon + don set each, which comes with a mini don (mine was a maguro set with japanese pickles and fermented soya beans- very reminiscent of the Japanese rice breakfasts I had in Japan!). I was also pleasantly surprised by the udon which isnt the normal thick noodle you would get, but a much thinner version. Sets were really worth the price- $13.40.We probably would not have ordered the sets if we had known just how delish the sushi would be. We tried various types like the ike (white squid), which was a huge white piece of squid on a smaller rice. I really liked how they dont use too much rice in their sushi so you can eat more without feeling too full. Also a must try is their ABURI SALMON sushi which was so fantastic we ordered another portion.Service is great- perhaps because the staff were really Japanese! We were served promptly and politely by all the staff, although they were busy cleaning up by then as it was rather late and close to closing time. Highly recommended and a must try for all Japanese food enthusiasts.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Maguro donburi

CFM9wXd5FFehlgFLmlfbgA.text: so the niners failed in their quest for yet another superbowl title:(but we still need to eat lunch, right?:)marcus and carol beckoned us to join them at liang court and we obliged.so obviously we take a cab from the exchange to liang court, right?wrong, my fellow yelpers suggested we walk and walk we did!talk about working up an appetite!but this place was well worth the trudge.in fact, it would easily be the best conveyor belt sushi in town.clean, fresh, friendly.very wallet friendly without compromising on quality!i only had their fuji sushi set but based on that and what the rest had from the conveyor belt, the quality is definitely there.service was good too.prompt tea refills.smiles all round.gentle unsolicited recommendations.extra info on their offerings.and when it came to settling of the bill, no complains whatsoever when we wanted individual split billing.not your shinji for sure but also not their stratospheric prices!

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. fuji sushi set.
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. tables away from conveyor belt.
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. booth seating.

IfgoHgGA8PjAc1Lfxt6Psg.text: Went to try out this restaurant as my friends and I have yet try this. What attracted me was the Bara chirashi when I was queuing for a space to seat.Was seated quite quickly as we chose to seat outdoors. The indoor seats were quickly filled up. - Wednesday night Looking at the overall interior design, I enjoy the materials they use. Soft coloured materials which were pleasing to the eyes. There were a table with half sofa and half chair. I sat myself on the end of the sofa.Ordered the food on the touch screened tablet. Food came much earlier than expected.First dish to arrive was the salmon sashimi. It is fresh but not cold enough. 6 pieces for $5.80. Not too bad for the price I guess.Then my friends' ramen arrived. It seemed that they enjoyed their food as there wasn't any ingredients left on their bowls.Next was the Bara Chirashi. I ordered the smaller bowl but it came in a bigger portion than I expected. The sashimi was fresh. I like the mixture of seaweed, salmon roe, a few types of sashimi, cucumber in cube forms. Like I mentioned earlier, I prefer it to be much colder than it should. But overall it was tasty and delicious.Drink wise I ordered ice lemon tea. I like the home made blend of the ice lemon tea. Is very refreshing :)Overall, it was a good choice - price and food was much better than expected. Will be there again in the future :)

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore

OVsKho31JyUFWRXvTYTh7w.text: Yummy fresh sushi!!! I strongly recommend the aburi salmon, the ikura and everything on the conveyor belt. Also do note that the prices of the sashimi is the same price as the sushi... and sitting by the conveyor belt is the best thing to do, if you can't control yourself and hate waiting for food to be prepared! The big eel sushi for $8 is yummy! I know $8 for one piece of sushi.... But it's so good!

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Aburi salmon!! We had 4 plates of this!!
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. The giant eel sushi $8!!
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Cheese and tobiko! The tobiko is so crunchy and yummy!

0UG51It93oAJr2dUEceudw.text: This was my first time in Liang Court.  Great place to go if you're missing Japan.  Lots of Japanese stores and restaurants to choose from.We found this place on Yelp and wanted to try out a new place outside our own neighborhood.  This was tucked away in a corner of the mall next to the food market.  The sign really just looks like Ryoshi Sushi, FYOIAnyway - the food: Great value and variety of sashimi. LOVED the big bowl of miso - so different!  The fish was fresh and delicious, but there was not any creativity in it, nor was it much different than other sushi places I've been to in Singapore.  Of course, I'm a white girl that loves my California sushi, so I may not have the best palate for authentic Japanese sushi... but this felt more like a TRUE Japanese sushi experience than any other restaurant I've been to in Singapore.  No, I did not try the raw whitefish staring back at me every time it passed me on the conveyor belt, yes I did stick to mainly salmon and tuna and veggie rolls - but I'll be going back, and I just might be in the mood for raw octopus next time.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Our mountain of plates

p0Hhre2HUZVyl6d8AfNNfQ.text: I ordered mega Fuji $55, it contains sea urchin, ikura and crab meat. The sea urchin was spoil and it really smells like shit. The ikura taste very fishy too. We told the Pino cashier but she didn't do anything about it. End up we just left all the left over on the table. Well, I accidentally consumed one piece of spoil sea urchin, yes... Down to food poisoning = stomach ache and diarrhea.We also ordered a bowl of mixed sashimi and eel rice. There are a few pieces of the raw fish taste not fresh (spoil too). We don't bother to finish it. Green tea x 2Ginger ale x 1Mega Fuji (uni, ikura and crab meat)Sashimi lunch set x 1A bowl of sashimi with eel x 1Udon x 1 Oyster with ponzu x 1 Total bill $134Actually I am quite disappointed. This restaurant with such a high review in yelp yet most of their sashimi and food are not fresh. I paid 134 to got into food poisoning.

W-P1-6bYRwXnbOwKD-prkQ.text: We could have sushi here all day and night. Salmon -aburi, -tamanegi, or just plain ol' BIG. Honmaguro akami, maguro, chutoro, ohtoro. It can go on and on.. Im not that adventurous when it comes to sushi but the variety here is quite amazing!A conveyor belt for added incentive if you can't wait for your food. Plates will range from $1.80 to $6.80. Specials and and ala carte round out their offerings. Simple, casual place where they serve good quality sushi.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Aburi salmon sushi heaven
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Also available, tempura (light and delicate) with udon noodles
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Blue fin tuna

udHTNJsJNEfbY_BE0d_Ynw.text: I really like the aburi salmon even though I don't usually eat raw salmon. I had some raw oyster sushi on rice but I think I probably much prefer just the oyster alone as the rice does not really complement the oyster. My friends love their negitoro roll. The price is reasonable. I also tried their Sakura ebi which comes in a pair on the plate. I much prefer it cooked cos it bring out the fragrance of cooked shrimp. For 6.80, it is worth a try to see if you like it.

photos.caption: Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Ryoshi Sushi IkeIkeMaru - Singapore, Singapore. Sakura ebi sushi! Try it :)

kT1rPDOQLgpXbRZOURmFxw.text: When we last visited, some of the chefs were no longer there. We didn't enjoy the meal as much as than in previous visits and we felt they standards may have dropped. We'll try it again another time to give it another shot.

C1dWilJGX4PJpcWrl3NMvg.text: I fell in like with sushi here... and I don't say this frivolously.I'm not a big raw fish eater, but there was something about what I saw on the conveyor belts on my first vist that just drew me in... I'd never really enjoyed sashimi (stop judging, guys, i know it's a #firstworldproblem), always having that token piece, then feeling a little meh about it, and then I came here, and it felt like my palate was liberated, and I suddenly enjoyed it. BIZARRE. I've tried so many different kinds here now, and I don't mean tamago/inari/tuna mayo-style, but otoro, maguro, ika, aji, hamachi, and loads more I don't remember or can't pronounce. And each piece has what feels like a pinky-sized portion of rice, to a whopper of a slice of fish. It's hard not to taste the awesomeness of the fish, or see the value in what you're getting. Prices are ridiculous for this quality, and in a good way. And that's made the experience all the better!

jqd0UhBxMkCVmRb_CMS9PQ.text: As I've mentioned in previous reviews, my ability to eat inferior sushi in Singapore has definitely taken a hit since I returned to Japan after a long absence.I'll confess. I've never paid more than $150 per head for Japanese food. I've paid more than this for non-Japanese food but I've never been to one of these super amazeballs $400 a head sushi joints like Shini by Kanesaka or Tetsuya's or what have you. It's on the to-do list, trust me. But until then, the sushi I ate at a tiny joint called Kouraku in Nakameguro/Daikanyama area, Tokyo (check it out if you're in town) is the yardstick for any and all other sushi.So Ikeikemaru was obviously no Kouraku. But it wasn't bad, I guess. I understand that they get their sushi flown in on Tuesdays and Thursdays so maybe Sunday wasn't the best day to go. Having said this, the daimyo anago was pretty great and the salmon was competent, as was the aji.What was disappointing? The chu-toro which tasted less fresh and not as well cut, and the uni which tasted like some kind of citrus fruit.Bottom line is, this is the sort of quality you would expect while paying $50 a head for sushi in Singapore. It doesn't blow anyone's mind but it's better than many other, crappier sushi joints.By the way, for the record, I gotta say that I dig ordering directly via iPad.
